Hello World

To write "Hello World!" in Python, open IDLE and write the following code:

print("Hello World!")

Then at the top of IDLE click on "Run", then click "Run Module". It will open a new IDLE window and display "Hello World!" on the screen. You can also press F5 on your keyboard to run the module.

Declaring Variables

Creating a variable is as follows:

x = 10 y = "Harry"

Variables do not need a type identifier in front of the variable name. The type can even be changed after it has been declared.

x = 10 x = "Harry"

If you do, however, want a variable to be a specific type, that can be done via casting.

x = str(5) # x will be "5" y = int(5) # y will be 5 z = float(5) # z will be 5.0

If you want to know the type of a variable, you can do so using the type() function.

x = 10 print(type(x))
if-else-statement

The if-else-statement is a conditional statement to perform different actions for different decisions.

In Python we have the following conditional statements:

  • "if" statement to determine if a specified condition is true.
  • "else" statement if that same condition is false.
  • "elif" statement to specify a new condition to test, if the first condition is false.

    • Example of an "if" statement:

    if "condition": // block of code will execute if the condition is true

    Example of an "else" statement:

    if "condition": // block of code will execute if condition is true else: // block of code to be executed if condition is false

    Example of an "elif" statement:

    if "condition1": // block of code will execute if condition1 is true elif "condition2": // block of code to be executed if condition1 is false and condition2 is true else: // block of code to be executed if both condition1 and condition2 are false
    while statement

    A "while" statement loops through a block of code as long as the specified condition is true.

    Here is an example of a "while" statement:

    while "condition": // block of code will execute as long as the condtion remains true

    It is important to alter the condtion after every loop, or else it will create an infinite loop that will never end.

    Function Declaration

    A function is a block of code that runs only when the function is called

    To declare a function, it must include:

  • The name of the function
  • A set of arguments to the function, if any

    • This is what a function in Python looks like:

    def function_name(parameter1, parameter2): // block of code that will execute when the function is called

    To call the function you do:

    function_name(argument1, argument2)

    In this example the function, "function_name" expects 2 arguments. If there are not 2 arguments when it is called, there will be a runtime error.
